stages.description: A tiny achene, silver-white with fine lengthwise ribs. Requires light to germinate — do not bury deep.
One of the quickest-sprouting vegetables — a threadlike radicle emerges within days in cool, moist soil. Germination stalls above 27°C.
Two small spoon-shaped cotyledons open. First true leaves appear pale and slightly cupped, already hinting at the soft texture to come.
The rosette fills quickly. Outer leaves fold loosely inward, building the characteristic soft head. This is the harvest window — tender, buttery, mildly sweet.
Heat triggers bolting: a central stalk shoots up dramatically in days. Leaves turn bitter and tough almost overnight as the plant redirects energy to seed.
Small yellow composite flowers open along tall branching stalks. Fluffy white pappus forms on mature seeds, ready for wind dispersal.
Stalks dry and hollow. Seeds scatter on the breeze. The plant collapses back into the soil, leaving volunteers as a promise for next season.

companions.lore: Shallow-rooted lettuce and deep-rooted carrots occupy different soil layers without competing. Lettuce's leaf canopy shades the soil surface, keeping it cool and moist — a benefit for both crops.
In midsummer heat, lettuce bolts quickly in full sun. Planted beneath the canopy of tomato plants, it gains enough shade to extend the harvest window by several weeks.
Lettuce and alpine strawberries share a preference for cool, moist soil. Interplanted, they form a living ground cover that suppresses weeds and retains moisture for both crops.

stages.description: Pale yellow patches appear between the veins of outer leaves. Flip a leaf — a faint gray-lavender fuzz is forming on the underside. Bremia lactucae, the lettuce specialist.
Yellow patches turn tan and papery. Spore masses on the undersides become dense and gray. Outer leaves collapse, wetting the inner head and accelerating spread to neighboring plants.
Pale green aphids cluster in the crinkled inner leaves, nearly invisible against the foliage. Sticky honeydew coats nearby surfaces.
Inner leaves cup and curl as colonies expand. Ants may be seen farming the aphids. New growth emerges stunted and malformed.
Heavy infestation causes overall yellowing. The inner head fails to form. Unsalvageable for table use, though still safe to eat if washed very thoroughly.

lore.description: The quintessential garden salad green — pale, buttery, quick to mature, and swift to bolt. Butterhead forms a soft, loose head that melts in the mouth, but demands cool weather and rewards attentive timing.
lore.origin: Cultivated from wild Lactuca serriola across the Mediterranean and Near East since antiquity; butterhead types formalized in 19th-century European market gardens
lore.fun_fact: Lettuce contains trace amounts of lactucarium — a milky latex from its stem — with mild sedative properties. Ancient Romans ate lettuce at the end of meals to aid sleep, and 19th-century physicians prescribed lettuce preparations as a painkiller substitute.
